name: Isabella P. AOSE
comment info:
This graph shows the attempted crossings at the U.S. southern border in 2023. In this graph, 1.8 million people who attempted to cross the border are in ongoing proceedings or legal limbo while 870,000 people have deportation orders, expulsion, etc. In addition, 600,000 immigrants entered undetected. Clearly, from this statistic, the border is not as secure as the government makes it seem as there is still a significant amount of people sneaking into this country illegally.  Title 42 says that when non-citizens enter the US on an illegal basis they will be processed for removal. Title 42 does not impose immigration or criminal consequences on migrants. Therefore, migrants who are expelled can repeatedly try and cross the border. I wonder how many migrants this past year attempted to cross the border for the 2nd, 3rd, or 4th time as a result of this law. I wonder how many of those migrants found undetected ways to enter. I also wonder why people would travel thousands of miles to this country and voluntarily depart once they begin being processed under Title 8. Is being processed really that bad? 180,000 people voluntarily departed once they began being processed under Title 8! This relates to me because my mom is an immigration lawyer and her job is to help people achieve immigration status in the United States. I am sure she is very familiar with all of this. 
"How Immigrants Make Their Way into the US"

name: Carlos M.
location: Perth Amboy High School P3 Stats
comment info:
Out of 2.5 million encounters in this graph, 1.8 million immigrants are either still pending legal proceedings or are in legal limbo. Out of them, only 2,700 have been granted relief or residency, while 870,000 have been deported. 3.1 million people tried to cross the southern border into the United States in 2023; 1.8 million of them succeeded in doing so, 870,000 of them left the country, and about 602,700 were either ignored or granted amnesty.
Given that Title 42 was more permissive than Title 8 in permitting several attempts to cross the southern border, its termination raises concerns about the fate of undocumented immigrants and the length of their legal limbo. It's unclear how many unauthorized immigrants there are and how long they've been in legal limbo.
Perth Amboy, where I live and work and which attracts a lot of immigrants, worries about the ongoing immigration issues that its residents face. In an effort to provide for their families and become financially successful in the future, many immigrants, both first and second-generation, put a lot of effort into their employment. Disturbing statistics reveal that over 800,000 people were deported and only 2,700 people received aid, highlighting the ongoing struggles in the community.
How are Immigrants moving to the U.S. handled?

comment info: The graph depicts how different people enter and interact with immigration in the United States. A large a number of people are made to leave under Title 42. I wonder what the parameters are around spelling people from the border and what makes them eligible for staying. I also notice how few cases are not border cases. name: Katherine H
comment info:
This graph shows how many people were believed to have attempted to cross the United States' southern border in 2023. In total, it is estimated that 3.1 million people tried to enter the US through the southern border. Out of the total, 1.8 million are going through legal endeavors because of their status, 870,000 were pushed back to their native country, and around 602,700 people have gone undetected or were granted amnesty. Considering so many people were turned away from the US under Title 42, what will happen now that Title 42 has come to an end? Title 42 was lenient in the sense that, unlike Title 8, people attempting to cross the southern border could try again and again; no one was banned. Will future policies on immigration begin to get more strict? Will those already integrated into American society who may lack citizenship be harmed? As New Jersey is an asylum state, many immigrants in my community have not been granted citizenship yet. In the upcoming presidential election, with immigration and borders being a highlighted topic, I worry for the members of my community and how this could impact them.

“Crossing The Southern Border: The Odds of Success”

name: Katherine H
comment info:
This graph shows how many people were believed to have attempted to cross the United States' southern border in 2023. In total, it is estimated that 3.1 million people tried to enter the US through the southern border. Out of the total, 1.8 million are going through legal endeavors because of their status, 870,000 were pushed back to their native country, and around 602,700 people have gone undetected or were granted amnesty. Considering so many people were turned away from the US under Title 42, what will happen now that Title 42 has come to an end? Title 42 was lenient in the sense that, unlike Title 8, people attempting to cross the southern border could try again and again; no one was banned. Will future policies on immigration begin to get more strict? Will those already integrated into American society who may lack citizenship be harmed? As New Jersey is an asylum state, many immigrants in my community have not been granted citizenship yet. In the upcoming presidential election, with immigration and borders being a highlighted topic, I worry for the members of my community and how this could impact them.

“Crossing The Southern Border: The Odds of Success”

name: Katherine H
comment info:
This graph shows how many people were believed to have attempted to cross the United States' southern border in 2023. In total, it is estimated that 3.1 million people tried to enter the US through the southern border. Out of the total, 1.8 million are going through legal endeavors because of their status, 870,000 were pushed back to their native country, and around 602,700 people have gone undetected or were granted amnesty. Considering so many people were turned away from the US under Title 42, what will happen now that Title 42 has come to an end? Title 42 was lenient in the sense that, unlike Title 8, people attempting to cross the southern border could try again and again; no one was banned. Will future policies on immigration begin to get more strict? Will those already integrated into American society who may lack citizenship be harmed? As New Jersey is an asylum state, many immigrants in my community have not been granted citizenship yet. In the upcoming presidential election, with immigration and borders being a highlighted topic, I worry for the members of my community and how this could impact them.

“Crossing The Southern Border: The Odds of Success”

name: Manny
comment info:
1. 3.1 million people attempted border crossings into U.S. territory. 600 thousand went undetected, 565 thousand were expelled under Title 42 (and later deported), and 2.5 million were processed under Title 8. Out of those 2.5 million, 185 thousand faced expedited removal and were later deported, 180 thousand voluntarily departed and were later deported, 1.5 million were added to court cases, and 300 thousand were paroled. As a remainder of the 2.5 million, 1.8 million are in ongoing proceedings or “legal limbo”.
	What I took away from this was that the majority of people immigrating into the U.S. are currently involved in court cases/legal limbo. Only 2.7 thousand people were let into the U.S, which was really surprising and sad to see, considering 3.1 million people tried to get into the U.S. which means roughly only 0.08% of people got into the U.S. legally.
2. How do they know that 600 thousand people made it undetected?
How do they know that this estimate is accurate?
3. For me, this doesn’t really have an impact on my community, since we aren’t that close to the Southern immigration flow. Because of this, I can't really speak from experience, but I will say that the way the borders have been handled lately, is just not good enough.

name: Caruso
comment info:

Only 2700 people out of the 1.5 million new-for-2023 immigration court cases receive relief and are allowed to stay in the US.

I wonder why so few people (2.7k) eventually receive relief when the vast majority (1.8m) of people who are hoping to stay in the US are stuck in legal limbo or trying their best to make a case in an ongoing proceeding

In the tri-state area, we don’t necessarily take the brunt of the Southern border immigration flow. Yet we have the education to realize that wrong is happening at the border and in court for migrants at the Southern border, and we wish for change. I've always been frustrated by the way the Southern border has been handled and how those wishing to stay in the US are callously left in limbo by paperwork and trivialities. This graph shows just more of the same, which it should not. There needs to be change, and I hope our generation can rise and make that change.

The Quantified Flow of Southern Border Crossings.

name: Adam
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
The majority of migrants do not end up in a state of resolutions, but are caught up in “legal limbo” or ongoing cases. The next largest group is deported or expelled, while only a tiny fraction of the people (less than 0.1%) are granted relief legally. The only realistic way for them to enter the country is to do so undetected, which an estimated 600k do, since an encounter with customs all but guarantees rejection or an indeterminate result.

2. What do you wonder?

What does deportation/expulsion look like? Is there a specific protocol for bringing them back, or do they just get told to walk in the other direction? Also, what differentiates those granted relief from the vast majority who are not? Is there a special criteria they must meet? Lastly, what are “non-border cases”, and how do they enter the picture?

3. What impact does this have on you and your community?
I’m not sure that there are many migrants who arrive in my local area, but this certainly has an impact on my larger, national community. The large number of migrants can have an impact on cities that they arrive in. In some cases, this means filling jobs which are unwanted by other parts of the population, or in some cases by putting a stress on welfare systems. It also has an impact on politics, since immigration issues can polarize people’s views.

Legal Limbo: The Fate of People Entering America
